subhed: The killing of 20-year-old Mehdi Kessaci drew thousands into the streets, where his brother Amine, a well-known local figure in the fight against the devastation caused by drug trafficking, told the crowd: 'For years we have been raising the alarm… silence kills.'

title: How the US tried to undermine the G20 summit in South Africa
subhed: Washington is boycotting the event taking place on Saturday and Sunday in Johannesburg. Yet despite intimidation from the Trump administration, South Africa has pushed ahead with its agenda, placing the priorities of developing countries at the heart of the summit – the first G20 ever held in Africa.

title: Ukraine and US to hold talks in Switzerland on Trump's plan to end war
The 'everlasting peace' in Gaza promised by Trump is off to a troubled start
subhed: The US president described the UN Security Council's vote on phase II of his peace plan as the dawn 'a golden age for the Middle East.' But how can we separate this bluster from actual reality, asks Le Monde columnist Alain Frachon.

title: Activist Amine Kessaci: 'No, I will not stay silent. I will say and repeat that my brother Mehdi died for nothing. I will speak out about the violence of drug trafficking'
subhed: Known for his fight against the devastation caused by drug trafficking in the working-class neighborhoods of Marseille, the brother of Mehdi, aged 20, who was murdered on November 13, denounces 'the cowardice of those who order these crimes' and urges the French state to 'understand that a fight to the death is underway.'

title: The fall of Northvolt, Sweden's symbol of green reindustrialization
subhed: On March 12, the electric battery giant shut its doors for good. Nearly 5,000 people employed at the Skelleftea gigafactory lost their jobs. As the US-based company Lyten prepares to restart production, Northvolt's downfall has cast a chill over Sweden's ambitions to reindustrialize around clean technology.
